definitions.definition: to make somebody unable to think clearly or understand something

examples.text: These two sets of statistics are guaranteed to confuse the public.
They confused me with conflicting accounts of what happened.
Seeing the two of them together totally confused me.
They have deliberately confused the general public with their claims.

definitions.definition: to think wrongly that somebody/something is somebody/something else
definitions.sensetop: confuse A and Bconfuse A with Bconfuse A for B

examples.text: People often confuse me and my twin sister.
Be careful not to confuse quantity with quality.
She says that meteors breaking apart can easily be confused for UFOs.
I sometimes confuse Jane with her sister.
You can easily confuse the two paintings.
An apology for something should not be confused with genuine remorse.
The Tasmanian wolf is not to be confused with the dingo.
The condition can sometimes be confused for influenza.

definitions.definition: to make a subject more difficult to understand

examples.text: His comments only served to confuse the issue further.
There are too many different rules confusing the situation.
Just to confuse matters, they have decided to give all the streets new names.
His latest comments only serve to confuse the issue further.
I will try to be brief and avoid further confusing the issue.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘rout, bring to ruin’): from Old French confus, from Latin confusus, past participle of confundere ‘mingle together’. Originally all senses of the verb were passive, and therefore appeared only as the past participle confused; the active voice occurred rarely until the 19th cent. when it began to replace confound.
